Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 07:24AM lwarstler wrote: JamJam, If there is one near you, I would go see a breast specialist or ask your doctor for a referral to one. The, "I can't biopsy it because it is deep" statement doesn't make sense to me. Mine was very deep (especially because I am very large, an F) to the point that not one of my doctors, nor myself was ever even able to feel it and it was almost 3 cm. It was difficult for her to get to and she really had to push hard but she was able to get to it. There are also many types of biopsies that can be used based on the situation, size, location, etc. Maybe s/he is right, but I would see someone who specializes in breast health even if it is just for your own peace of mind.
Posts.Title: Anyone told they're too young? jamjam29 kennessee

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2011 08:27PM lwarstler wrote: Especially here, you will never be alone :) Gottobeme said it best about how this affects us emotionally. When people try to make you stop feeling bad, they are not doing it to help you, they are doing it to get rid of the uncomfortable feeling they have from seeing you upset and not being able to do anything about it. Right now, you need people who can focus on you and what you need. My mom had breast cancer 7 years ago and I still had to remind her that being scared is totally normal and acceptable and that telling me not to worry was just making me feel like I wasn't "doing cancer right." I won't presume to know how your family will react, but if you think they will react positively, you might concider telling them what type of support you need. I actually had to tell my husband that I just needed him to listen to me cry and complain and then just agree with me that it all really sucks. I think the crabby is normal too. I have been on a roller coaster of emotions since the beginning..and am also at home all day while the kids and my husband are gone. To fill my quite times, I come here and post on the boards to keep myself grounded. Otherwise, my mind does go everywhere. Take care of yourself, hugs and warm thoughts coming your way.
Posts.Title: Did any of you get crabby or depressed before lumpectomy? tjohnson1971 Natters

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2011 06:47PM lwarstler wrote: {{{HUGS}}} How truly blessed to have had such a love. Thoughts and prayers are with you and your family.

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 10:59AM lwarstler wrote: Kim, Do you drink a lot of coffee or caffeine? I get that under my right arm sometimes too and my doctor told me that it was a little swolen but felt like it might be from too much coffee. She told me to drink a lot of water for several weeks and see what happens. I did and it did go away. I have noticed that whenever I don't drink enough coffee it comes back.
Posts.Title: Got report. Birads 4. What does it mean? Kimmer1975 Kimmer1975

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2011 06:42PM lwarstler wrote: Kim, What you are going through, the waiting game, is really hard ont he psychy. I think all the waiting was hardest for me so far. Once we had all the answers and plan, i was actually able to really calm down. Until then though, I feel you on the cranky part. I was up and down all over the place and it really is understandable. I'm sorry to hear about your loneliness, it sound like you have had a lot of loss in your life. Is there any chance your mom could come visit for a few days to give you someone you can talk to? I too am a stay at home mom in a new town where I don't know many people. Is there a cancer center near your house. Go there and talk to the social worker if they have one, she may be able to find a group that is meeting for people who are waiting on results. Also, LittleMelons is right, you really shouldn't have to wait. I would call you family doctor and see if they can call and get your results for you. There is no reason for them not to. My doctor was going out of town and I had her leave permission with one of the nurses to call me with the results. I would push hard to get your answers before the end of the month. That's just really hard to wait for and there's no reason to suffer that if you don't absolutely have to. Hugs, Lee Ann

Posts.Title: And it keeps getting worse... Michele_T lhasamom

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2011 08:34AM lwarstler wrote: Martygra, My chemo starts the 27th, so just a few days before you. My chemo will be for 18 weeks so we will be starting radiation about the same time too I think. Have you read the September 2011 chemo thread? There are lots of women sharing their recent experience and they have listed tons of suggestions for things to make it easier. A very standard aggressive treatment seems to be dose dense (given every 2 weeks) AC 4 times, followed by T every 2 wks 4 times.That could be what she was talking about. I learned after my first phone call to make sure I brought someone to each of my appointments because emotions get the best of me and I can't remember. I'm so sorry about your work situation, I know it must be difficult, there are several women on the chemo thread who continue to work and may be of good support as well, its under the Chemotherapy-before, during and after thread at http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/69/topic/773805?page=14#idx_417 I'm doing ok most days but I definitely have my ups and downs. So sorry we are here, this really sucks but we will get through it together, (((big hugs)))
Posts.Title: Off to the doctor today. martygra martygra

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 12:35PM lwarstler wrote: Martygra,  So glad your SNB went well. It really can be so hard to take care of ourselves and let others take care of us but whiterabbit is right, you just need to do what you feel up to mentally or physically and just not worry about the rest. I love the analogy about the elephant, and it sounds good to me. It really is mentally exhausting and sounds silly but I am just looking forward to getting to the chemo part so we can stop all the testing, cutting and planning and just know what I need to do for a few months. Sorry you are feeling so down, I hope you will start to feel better when all this gets resolved and you can just focus on getting well. {{Hugs}} , Lee Ann

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 02:29PM lwarstler wrote: I agree, I think they mostly want to know if you are going to be ok. I answer, "well, not as early as I would like, but early enough that we still feel confident that it will be treated successfully." It sems to satisfy people without feeling lke I am minimizing it.
Posts.Title: How do you answer "did they catch it early?" oaktownmom 208sandy

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 02:29PM lwarstler wrote: Matygra, So glad your boss responded that way. It is hard enough to deal with this diagnosis without having to also worry about your job. Hope everything went well for you today at the doctors. Lee Ann
Posts.Title: Off to the doctor today. martygra martygra

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 07:21AM lwarstler wrote: IBigs hugs to you Martygra, 'm so sorry about your diagnosis. I was scared to death too but Voracious is right that once you get a plan and start doing something, it starts to subside because you know you are fighting it. I think its normal to be freaked out. I gave myself a specific amount of time that I was allowed to freak out and made sure I freaked out to someone. I actually felt a lot better after and was more ready to fight and get involved. So, don't be too hard on yourself, just listen to yourself about what you need, tell someone and then keep going one day at a time. Slowly you will start to feel a little less traumatized. So sorry again, but you have really done amazingly well in handling things this far and you will get through this too when the shock wears off. Hugs, Lee Ann
Posts.Title: Off to the doctor today. martygra martygra

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 12:44PM lwarstler wrote: I'm so glad your boss is helping you out with that. It really can be kind of hard to hold it together when others are treating you like you are dying. My breast specialist and her nurse talked to me like they just told me I was going to die and it made me more upset than when I first heard it was cancer. I had this...wait...I'm not dying, I'm just sick feeling and it did make me gun shy to talk to anyone. I had my DH tell most people for me and then it wasn't so bad when I talked to them because they were over the shock. Whiterabbit said it best when she said that it is totally normal for you to be focused on this right now and that time is your friend. It does get a little easier...especially when you have all your answers,plans, etc...in place.  Don't worry about how anyone else will feel about how you handle things, you just do whatever you need to do for yourself right now. Hugs, sorry you are going through this and I hope everything goes super smooth for you. Lee Ann

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2011 09:45AM lwarstler wrote: There is a Dr. Ghassan Zalzaleh, MD at Associates in Medical Oncolgy in Tinley Park that my mother in law who lives in Gurnee says is really good. Several of her friends have gone there.
Posts.Title: Surgeon referal? key6687 key6687

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 08:51PM lwarstler wrote: Hi snoozle,  The early parts for me went really fast as well, mammos, ultrasounds, etc..all within just a couple of days. I had soreness but not on the side with the cancer...lol...but enough to make me think about getting things looked at. It is normal and easy to get scared about breast cancer, I'm sure especially so with your family history. Fuzzy gave good advice though to try your best to just take it one step at a time. The biggest issue I had while waiting was that I needed an answer so badly that I just tried to see hints or clues anywhere. Unfortunately, that sometimes helped and sometimes hurt, so if you can focus on just on step at a time it will help. Lee Ann
Posts.Title: breast clinic referal snoozles59 snoozles59

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2011 12:15PM lwarstler wrote: slgarcia05, A few weeks ago, I was where you are now...it is the worst, most helpless place to be and I remember feeling completely stupid for not asking questions about what it means that the cyst is "irregular shaped and more solid". My general practitioner also sent me to the surgeon for a consult and she did a core biopsy that day in her office. Evidently, it is not uncommon for surgeons to do that so you might want to consider having someone take you if possible. You might still be able to drive after, but I wouldn't have wanted to after mine as I was a little sore for a few days. Also, the earlier suggestion of starting a notebook is reallly great, because if it does show a malignancy, you will have many other appointments and it can be hard to keep track of when each test was done (every place will ask). It sounds like you have a great attitude about it. I think it is very healthy to have an "I expect it will most likely be benign but that there is a possibility of malignancy" view of the situation, as that is true. When the possibility of cancer even is out there, it is so normal to be concerned and it is frustrating no matter what you ask until you get a complete answer one way or the other. Peggy made a good point about stepping away sometimes, but I also understand how empowering information can feel when you are in the seemingly powerless position of waiting. I'm sorry you have to deal with that and I hope you have found a little peace in the answers and suggestions for preparation you have received.

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2011 08:55PM lwarstler wrote: Snoozle [[[hugs]]]. Even if it is a negative, which is the most common outcome, you are not wasting their time. Anytime there is an unexpected change in your breast it is time well spent making sure it is nothing serious. I knoww hard it is to keep your mind off of things so staying busy sounds like a good idea. Hugs and wishing you a busy, but restful weekend. You'll be in my thoughts Monday.

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2011 02:14PM lwarstler wrote: Topless adn beatup, You really have been beat up. My heart sincerely goes out to you. You may always look down and feel some sense of loss but it seems to me that in an uncerrtain future, it will be good to have one worry off your plate. I'm sure when the drains are out, you feel better and  you find alternative prosthesis, you will begin to feel better. In the mean time, it does sound like you have been through a lot and you may want to see if there is a support group you could join so you could talk with others going through some similar issues. I hope you are feeling better, and there is no question you are a survivor and as amazing as you have done to date, I'm sure you will continue. We all have our up and down days, I'm praying your get fewer and further apart soon. Hugs, Lee Ann
Posts.Title: Did I do the right thing? topless lwarstler

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 12:35AM lwarstler wrote: Oh man, what a rough evening it sounds like you had. I have decided google can be a vicious weapon for anxiety when it comes to cancer info. I started looking a little bit but stopped after I found this site. It was the only one that seemed to give just the known and important facts and didn't scare me to death!. I'm so sorry for this waiting game for you:( I'm glad that he is really being involved though as I know that, at least for me, it was nice when my husband got involved and I didn't feel like I was in this quite on my own. Sure hope you both can find some peace about things until you can get the results from that thoughtless doctor. {{hugs}}, Lee Ann
Posts.Title: The Risk % of Birads 4. HUGE discrepancy in numbers!!! Kimmer1975 Chickenpants

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2011 01:03PM lwarstler wrote: Hugs Mata, this period right after diagnosis and before a full plan is in place really was the hardest for me. I too cried often and just when I thought I was doing better would think of another thing I would worry about and start over again. I don't know what kind of biopsy you had but I had a core biopsy and it was still sore a couple weeks later. If it isn't getting any better or if it begins to hurt more, certainly have your doctor rule out any infection. If it is clear, it could be partly from your stress. Cycle-path is right about asking for help with your emotions if you need it and has given realing good advice. If there is a cancer center near you, they often have social workers who are primarily there to help you get through this that you could call and could help you as well. MIne was invaluable in talking me through one rough day and then setting me up with some resources to help address some of my concerns, including support groups.

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2011 03:22PM lwarstler wrote: Indimom, I am so glad you were able to get that time for you. It sounds like you have all been through a lot in the last several years. My heart and prayers are with you. Hope things all work out well, it sounds like you could really use it.
Posts.Title: Happy Bubble Popped: Blood in Nipple Discharge IndianaMomOf3 lwarstler

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 11:29AM lwarstler wrote: Indimom, So incredibly sorry about what you are dealing with. People who say not to worry have obviously not been in your position before or have never had to deal with the possibility of this diagnosis. Having also had a mom with breast cancer, I think it is even more worrying when that is the case and ou have watched someone struggle with this disease. Even though it is for after diagnosis, following the suggestions here : www.breastcancer.org/symptoms/... can help to make it a little easier. I think it is totally understandable to be a little freaked out and the only suggestion I have is to just keep talking about it. Talking about your feelings seems to make them a little less overwhelming. So sorry you are dealing with this.  I hope others will have more info about there experience to help.
Posts.Title: Happy Bubble Popped: Blood in Nipple Discharge IndianaMomOf3 lwarstler

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2011 07:32PM lwarstler wrote: Luckypenny, It is so frustrating when you keep going for answers and they just don't come. I'm not a doctor, so I won't try to analyze you have read. Two of my doctors told me the MRI gives a better picture and that often what they think is an issue the MRI shows isn't if it is any comfort that the MRI sounds like it looks better than the initial US. Unfortunately, what I do know is that you won't be able to tell for sure, until the biopsy results are back, if it really is or isn't cancerous. 100 people could tell you what they think and it wouldn't mean much until it does. Although it is hard to wait for the biopsy, when the results come back next week, you will finally get to find out for sure what it is. I know that 's not a lot of comfort for what you are going through now because this waiting game is really hard and I'm sure you must want to just scream at this point, but hang in there. You have made it this far and you will get through. So sorry you are dealing with all this...{hugs}
Posts.Title: MRI and Shadow luckypenny luckypenny

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2011 11:51PM lwarstler wrote: I sooo feel you. My kids are 15 and 12 and even though they are really good kids, I was snappy for days while I waited for answers. Maybe your S.O. can get you some free time by taking the kids for a bit so you can read and do what you need to for you to calm down. Fortunately, kids are resiliant and you will eventually get results and calm down. If you need to, I explained to mine that I was feeling a little cranky and that I thought it would get better in a couple of days but that I needed some calm down time for ow. I asked them to just chill out and give me some time to relax for a bit. I didn't give them any info about the biopsy or cancer. I hope you found some quiet time this evening to focus on you and get what you need.
Posts.Title: Feeling crabby clevelandgirl99 iLUV2knit

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 07:57PM lwarstler wrote: I found my voice in learning to be more assertive about my health care. I have found out that taking care of myself will not make everyone else feel unloved. I reallized that I am much stronger than I think and that even if I don't work I can still impact the world for the better. So far, I have developed an even stronger appreciation for my husband and how supportive he is and I have learned that my children are stronger and more capable than I ever gave them credit for. Lastly, I have really discovered how incredibly blessed I am and how many really wonderful strangers there are ot there who are willing to take time out of their busy days to share a word or experience they think will brighten my day or lighten my load.  Thanks ladies!
Posts.Title: What is your positive out of this negative situation? Kimmer1975 Kimmer1975

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2011 03:31PM lwarstler wrote: Bunka, I'm so sorry about your diagnosis and that you are here. I am really glad though taht you will get to see the surgeon tomorrow. Like you, I was confident in the negative results for the same reason and when it came back positive I was terrified and completely caught off guard. If all your pathology is back, the surgeon should be able to explain to you what grade and apparent stage you are, based on the size and type of cancer it is. In my case, they did an MRI and CT scan to look at the lymph nodes, but often they have to do a sentinel node biopsy to determine for sure if it is or is not in the lymph nodes. In the end, they did one for me. I'm not sure about whether or not they do that if you have a non-invasive cancer, like DCIS, so maybe someone else can explain what happens if they do that. If you haven't looked at it yet, reading about the types of cancer on this website will really help prepare you for your appointment tomorrow. It can help you understand what the doctor is saying and help prepare you for what questions you need to ask. Again, I'm really sorry for your diagnosis but you are in a great place for support. I've had my diagnosis just over a month and there are incredibly knowledgable and supportive people here who can help you get through this. Lee Ann
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed but only know it is breast cancer Nana2Six judyfams

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 07:36AM lwarstler wrote: For everyone struggling with constipation, don't know if anyone else hear has ever tried it, but when my mom had chemotherapy 7 years ago they gave her a prescription for Miralax. They have it over the counter now and since I have been struggling with being backed up for awhile, thanks to all my pain meds and muscle relaxers, I tried it and it seems to be working. I have also been eating 2 Activia a day to help so I'm not sure which is helping the most, but they seem to finally be getting me on track. Took about a week to get me regular but for the first time in over 2 years I finally am again. Just thought I'd share cause I had never heard of it before. Lee Ann
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 08:07AM lwarstler wrote: I know Activia has a type of live probiotics not found in all yogurts that are meant to specifically help with digestion and bowels. You can read about the difference at www.livestrong.com/article/254... . I eat regular yogurt all the time and it wasn't sufficient, but I'm sure it helps some. The Miralax is a white powder you stir in drinks, but I don't know if it is the same as Restoralax. You could compare the active ingredient, in Miralax it is 17g of Polyethylene glycol 3350.
